case_title: Syed WALAYAT HUSSAIN vs GOVERNMENT OF BALOCHISTAN and others

accussed_details.name: Syed Walayat Hussain
allegation: Murder of Naimat Ali under Section 302 PPC

complaint_summary: Appellant was accused of murdering Naimat Ali, leading to his suspension and dismissal from service.
investigation_summary: An FIR (No. 17 of 1993) was lodged on 25-3-1993 under Section 302 PPC at Qaidabad Police Station, Quetta. Appellant was arrested on 27-3-1993, and after investigation, a challan was submitted to the Sessions Judge, resulting in conviction and capital punishment on 27-12-1994.
judgment_summary: The appellant was acquitted of the murder charge based on a compromise with the deceased's legal heirs on 27-9-2002. His dismissal from service was overturned, and he was reinstated without back benefits, with the absence period treated as leave without pay.
punishment: Capital punishment (later acquitted based on compromise).
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; reinstatement in service without back benefits.

facts.position: Junior Clerk in Balochistan Reserve Police

appellant_counsel.name: W.N. Kholi
appellant_counsel.contention: Dismissal was based on criminal case conviction, which was later set aside due to compromise. Appellant is entitled to reinstatement with back benefits.

respondent_counsel.name: Salahuddin Mengal
respondent_counsel.contention: Acquittal was based on compromise, not on failure of prosecution. Appellant is not entitled to back benefits.

legal_arguments_summary: Defense argued that dismissal based on conviction was invalid after acquittal due to compromise, citing legal precedents.
Prosecution contended that acquittal was based on compromise, not lack of evidence, and appellant is not entitled to back benefits.

witness_statement.Ali Maded: Filed FIR alleging appellant committed murder of Naimat Ali.

appeal_number: Criminal Appeal No.2 of 1995; Criminal Petition No.315 of 1996
key_issues: Whether acquittal based on compromise is honourable.
Entitlement to reinstatement and back benefits after acquittal.

maxims.Acquittal: All acquittals are honourable regardless of the basis.

legal_terms.Acquittal: Judgment that a person is not guilty of the charges.
legal_terms.Compromise: Settlement between parties leading to dismissal of charges.

words_and_phrases.Honourable Acquittal: Legal term indicating acquittal without dishonor.

summary_vector_notes: Appellant was dismissed from service due to a murder conviction. He was later acquitted based on compromise with the deceased's heirs. The court reinstated him without back benefits, considering the acquittal honourable under legal precedents.
